subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
In the oracle bone script, it was an {{Han compound|酉|人|口|ls=ic|t1=bottle (of alcoholic beverages)|t2=person|t3=mouth (occasionally with the tongue protruding)|nocap=1}} – a person bending over a bottle to drink the alcoholic beverage. The droplets represented drops of the drink or saliva.

In the bronze script, the mouth separated from the body and corrupted into {{och-l|今}}, while the rest of the body became {{och-l|欠}}. These two components also acted as phonetic components. These changes were inherited in the seal script, leading ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' to interpret this character ({{zh-l|*㱃}}) as a {{Han compound|酓|欠|ls=psc|c1=p|c2=s|t2=yawn|nocap=1}}.

In the clerical script, {{zh-l|*酓}} has been modified to {{zh-l|*食|to eat}}, which is inherited in the current form.
